title: Garlic Dill Pickles
full_text:
Garlic Dill Pickles
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
15 mins
Cook
20 mins
Active
30 mins
Total
35 mins
Serves
10
to 12 servings
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
2 quarts
Kirby cucumbers
(approximately
3
pounds
)
8
garlic
cloves
, peeled
4
teaspoons
dill seeds
2
teaspoons
black
peppercorns
1
teaspoon
red chile flakes
1 1/2
cups
apple cider vinegar
1 1/2
cups
filtered
water
2
tablespoons
pickling salt
Directions
Wash jars thoroughly in warm, soapy water. If you plan on making shelf stable pickles, prepare a boiling water bath canner. Put fresh canning jar lids into a small saucepan with 3 inches of water and set to the barest simmer.
Wash and dry cucumbers. Remove blossom end. Cut into chips, spears or leave whole, depending on your preference.
Equally divide garlic cloves, dill seed, black peppercorns, and red chile flakes between jars. Pack prepared cucumbers into jars as tightly as you can without crushing them.
Combine vinegar, water, and salt in saucepan and bring to a boil.
Pour the brine into the jars, leaving 1/4 inch headspace (that's the amount of space between the surface of the brine and the rim of the jar).
Remove any air bubbles from jars by gently tapping them. You can also use a wooden chopstick or plastic utensil to help remove stubborn bubbles.
Wipe rims and apply lids and bands (don't screw them on too tightly).
If processing jars for shelf stability:
lower jars into your processing pot. When water returns to a boil, set a timer for 10 minutes.
When time is up, remove jars from canning pot and allow them to cool. When jars are cool enough to handle, check seals. Let pickles rest for at least 1 week before eating.
If you choose not to process your jars:
let them cool before putting them into the refrigerator. Do note that your jars may seal during the cooling process. However, without the boiling water bath process, that doesn't mean they're shelf stable. Still refrigerate.
Special Equipment
4 pint jars or 2 quart jars with lids and rings;
equipment for boiling-water bath canning
;
saucepan
